summary: In this context, ethane is analyzed in relation to its concentration in exhaled breath as a potential biomarker for lung cancer. The study finds no significant increase in exhaled ethane levels among lung cancer patients compared to healthy controls, indicating that ethane is not specifically associated with lung cancer. The findings suggest that measuring ethane in breath may not provide useful clinical information for diagnosing lung cancer, although the reproducibility of ethane levels in healthy individuals is noted.
